intro: Geanthus longipetalus, commonly known as the long-petaled geanthus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen shrub form. The plant produces showy, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or purple, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its foliage consists of elliptic, dark green leaves that are arranged in whorls along the stems. Geanthus longipetalus is often found in acidic, well-drained soils in woodland or scrub habitats.
